history.content:
In pre-Sahai semesters, it sounds like there was lots of coding that took place in the form of Kaggle competitions.

In fall17, it sounds like the code was slightly less of a priority; however, each p-set usually had at least one coding question. In those coding questions, we did things like implement linear regression, cross validation, decision trees, neural nets (and backprop), convolutional neural nets (using TensorFlow), etc. So there was still plenty of coding assignments, but the focus was definitely on the theory.

If you're looking for courses that may not go into the theory as much, you can try checking out 194/294-129 (Designing, Visualizing and Understanding Deep Neural Networks), 294-112 (Deep Reinforcement Learning), or 294-131 (Special Topics in Deep Learning). I can't say anything about these courses though, since I haven't taken any of them.

Also, I would like to say that although the theory doesn't seem immediately practical, I have found it to be enormously practical. Sure, if you're just doing stuff that's really well-tested and known to work (like training a conv-net on MNIST or CIFAR-10), then you can probably find some tutorial code online that works really well. However, once you start to do anything that's even a little out of the ordinary, things will go wrong, and knowing the theory of how things work will be an enormously helpful tool to understand why it's going wrong.

children.subject: You can’t do “practical” ML well without an understanding of the theory behind what you’re doing. If you want a less rigorous intro to the material, I’d suggest Data 100 (which does use scikit-learn).

history.content:
There's nothing quite so practical in the long run as a solid understanding of the fundamentals. Theory is a very important component of that, but it is not the only component.

For students who have the appropriate background (Math 53, EE16A, EE16B, probability at the level of EECS 126, programming experience at the level of 61B or beyond, and ideally EECS 127), 189 should be a course in which students experience a balanced diet of theory, implementation from scratch, using packages, and dealing with data sets (both real-world and synthetic). There is usually some programming-related assignment on every single problem set. And with the right background, students should get a lot out of every part.

This combination is chosen because that's the best way to actually understand something in a way that you can build upon it. Is 189 a complete ML-oriented degree by itself? The answer is no. of course not. Ideally, we would have a lot more HW problems with more parts each. But there are only 24 hours in a day and 189 is just one course. Does the ML trilogy of 126, 127, and 189 give students what they need to be able to self-study effectively and engage with ML material, both to deepen their understanding as well as engage practically? Yes. Probably another semester or two worth of self-study (including projects pursued on your own) beyond that core upper-division ML trilogy would make students extremely competitive at the bachelor's level for essentially any project that requires ML training. 

Finally, are there other ML-oriented courses that adjust the balance of coverage to be on things that are more immediately useful in practice? Yes! IEOR offers some for example, within the college of engineering itself. It is a tradeoff between long-term and short-term.

children.subject: The coding is embedded in the psets, not labs..
So is 189 like 126? You learn theory in class then you have an coding lab where you test that theory.

history.content:
I understand that CS 189 is an advanced UG/introductory graduate level course intended to deepen the theoretical understanding of machine learning, but what are the "practical" components of CS 189?

By "practical" I mean will there be any projects/hands-on assignments related to the things we learn in the course? Or is it mostly pset/theory-based?

Are there any classes that deal with the "practical" aspects of ML? Thank you.
history.subject: "Practicality" of CS 189?
